quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Answer Engine Optimization is how do I show up in LLMs as an answer?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A crisp definition of AEO that reframes optimization around being selected as the answer inside LLM outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But that's not the case in the LLM, because the LLM is summarizing many citations, and so you need to get mentioned as many times as possible.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Explains the core AEO mechanic: winning shifts from ranking #1 to maximizing credible mentions across sources that LLMs cite/summarize.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can get mentioned by a citation tomorrow and start showing up immediately. You can have a Reddit thread, you can have a YouTube video.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Highlights a fast feedback loop for AEO and points to specific channels practitioners can use to earn mentions quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Significantly more valuable. Webflow saw a 6X conversion rate difference between LLM traffic and Google Search traffic.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point suggesting LLM-driven traffic can convert materially better than traditional search traffic.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Google's slice of the pie stays the same. The pie gets bigger.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model that challenges the “Google is dying” narrative by framing AI search as expanding total demand rather than replacing it.

quotes.topic_title: How big a change is AEO?
quotes.text: And that was when you could do mass, auto-generated landing pages.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concrete example of an earlier SEO era that sets up how major algorithm shifts can invalidate entire playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: How big a change is AEO?
quotes.text: So essentially, you went from the SEO being spam to not spam.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for the Panda-era shift that reframes “big changes” as changes in what gets rewarded.

quotes.topic_title: How big a change is AEO?
quotes.text: That was probably the biggest change, and then this is probably the second-biggest change.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A contrarian calibration that challenges the common belief that AEO is the single biggest disruption in SEO history.

quotes.topic_title: How big a change is AEO?
quotes.text: I think that the main thing here is it is related to search, but it's a summarization of search and there's new inputs.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A succinct framework for AEO: search is shifting from retrieval to LLM summarization, changing what inputs matter for visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AEO vs GEO
quotes.text: So AEO and GEO are essentially trying to describe the same thing, which is how do I show up in LLMs as an answer?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Defines AEO/GEO with a practitioner-oriented goal: optimizing to appear as the answer inside LLM outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AEO vs GEO
quotes.text: And I personally prefer Answer Engine Optimization versus Generative Engine Optimization, because generative, you can generate images and videos and things other than an answer. Whereas answer is more narrowly defined, so my personal preference is we're talking about optimizing LLMs.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Offers a naming/positioning framework: focus on “answers” to keep the optimization target narrow and clear.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AEO vs GEO
quotes.text: It's interesting because recently, I don't know if I told you this, but I was looking at my referral traffic. And I found that ChatGPT is driving more traffic to my newsletter than Twitter, which I did not see coming.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive data point suggesting LLMs can already outperform major social platforms as a traffic source.

quotes.topic_title: Why LLM referrals are rising now
quotes.text: And I found that ChatGPT is driving more traffic to my newsletter than Twitter, which I did not see coming.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing LLMs can already outperform major social platforms as a referral channel.

quotes.topic_title: Why LLM referrals are rising now
quotes.text: Companies that we work with started in January and it started, one, because of more adoption, but two is because the answers became a bit more clickable.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Pinpoints a timing inflection (January) and a two-factor causal model practitioners can watch for: adoption + clickability.

quotes.topic_title: Why LLM referrals are rising now
quotes.text: You have maps, you have shopping carousels, you have clickable cards. So I think the clickability of the answer is increased, and then the adoption increased and that was around January.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Highlights specific “clickable surfaces” (maps, shopping, cards) as the mechanism behind rising LLM referrals—useful for optimization focus.

quotes.topic_title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
quotes.text: Yeah. I agree and disagree, but the way that I think about it is anything can be optimized. You just need to understand the underlying systems and the rules of the game, and if you do that, then you can optimize anything.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A practical mental model: optimization is possible if you learn the system mechanics and incentives.

quotes.topic_title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
quotes.text: What I think he probably meant by that, he probably meant two things. One is, "Please don't spam my product." And two is, "If you do, I will see it and I will stop you from doing that."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Reframes “just write great content” as partly an anti-spam warning and enforcement promise.

quotes.topic_title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
quotes.text: So it's not a long-term, robust strategy to create spam, just like it wasn't a long-term, robust strategy to create spam on Google.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable caution that spammy AEO tactics may work briefly but are structurally unstable over time.

quotes.topic_title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
quotes.text: Eventually, Google was going to say, "Huge shopping comparison sites are making 100 million auto-generated search pages and I don't like it, and I'm going to get rid of the whole category."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Concrete example (and scale) illustrating how platforms eventually clamp down on entire spam-driven categories.

quotes.topic_title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
quotes.text: And they'll have a whole team looking at that and then they'll change your algorithm to prevent you from doing that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Operational reality: anti-spam is an active, staffed effort that leads to rapid algorithmic countermeasures.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
quotes.text: So the specific things that we've done there, one is just traditional SEO. So make landing pages for high-search volume keywords, like best no-code website designer.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Concrete, repeatable tactic: build keyword-targeted landing pages to drive both SEO and AEO visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
quotes.text: Yeah. So I would say everything that works in SEO works in AEO, but there are additional things beyond SEO that also work in AEO.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A clear mental model that reframes AEO as inclusive of SEO plus extra distribution/citation work.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
quotes.text: Even if Webflow's URL shows up number one on the citations, they're not going to win the answer because their URL showed up number one, but at Google they would win.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Counterintuitive difference vs Google: top citation placement alone may not secure the LLM’s recommended answer.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
quotes.text: Because the LLM is summarizing many citations and so you need to get mentioned as many times as possible.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable AEO principle: optimize for breadth/frequency of mentions across sources, not just ranking a single page.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
quotes.text: So tried a bunch of stuff. Stuff that worked especially well was just straight SEO, number one. Number two is YouTube videos, and then the third is Reddit optimization.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Specific channel prioritization based on observed results: SEO first, then YouTube, then Reddit.

quotes.topic_title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
quotes.text: my first response is, "Don't do it at all. Spend your time on something else because you're not going to be able to grow SEO early on in search."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Contrarian guidance for startups: traditional SEO is often a poor early-stage bet due to slow compounding and authority constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
quotes.text: That's not the case for Answer Engine Optimization, because you can get mentioned by a citation tomorrow and start showing up immediately.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable AEO model: prioritize fast, fresh citations that can translate into immediate visibility in LLM answers.

quotes.topic_title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
quotes.text: So early-stage companies can win, they can win quickly. And they can win quickly and anyone can win quickly, by getting mentioned as many times as possible by the citations.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Clear AEO playbook: maximize breadth of mentions across sources rather than chasing a single top ranking.

quotes.topic_title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
quotes.text: So the average number of words, I think, Perplexity said this to somebody else, said that it was around 25 words, where versus Google words it's around six words.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Concrete data point supporting the idea that chat expands the long-tail by enabling longer, more specific queries than search.

quotes.topic_title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
quotes.text: And so there's all these questions that have never been asked or searched for before that are now being asked, and then you can win that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Strategic opportunity: target novel, ultra-specific conversational queries where incumbents may have no established advantage.

quotes.topic_title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
quotes.text: They are significantly more valuable. So Webflow, we saw a 6X conversion rate difference between LLM traffic and Google Search traffic.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing LLM-driven traffic can convert dramatically better than traditional search traffic.

quotes.topic_title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
quotes.text: Six times so significantly more qualified.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Memorable, quotable takeaway that frames LLM traffic as higher-intent and higher-quality leads.

quotes.topic_title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
quotes.text: Probably it's because you're so primed because you're having a conversation with multiple follow-ups, and so there's so much intent that you've built.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable mental model: conversational follow-ups “prime” users and build intent before they ever click through.

quotes.topic_title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
quotes.text: And you've probably really narrowed in on what you want, so when you're going somewhere, it's probably highly qualified.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Explains why downstream conversion improves: LLM users self-qualify by narrowing requirements prior to visiting a product site.

quotes.topic_title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
quotes.text: People trust ChatGPT to tell them the answer, and if you are the answer, you have so much advantage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Contrarian positioning insight: winning in answer engines can create disproportionate trust and conversion advantage versus ranking in search.

quotes.topic_title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
quotes.text: The other things, so I would break it up into stuff on your site, onsite and offsite. So onsite would be traditional SEO. The difference would be this long tail. I would also say that the difference is lots of follow-up questions about does your product do this thing? What are the use cases, features, integrations, languages?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A practical AEO framework: split efforts into onsite vs offsite, with onsite focused on long-tail, follow-up product capability questions.

quotes.topic_title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
quotes.text: The other strategy is the whole purpose of Reddit is to post useful, high-quality, authentic comments from real people. So at Webflow, we have a couple of people at Webflow going to comments and saying, "This is my name, this is where I work, and here's a useful piece of information." So the strategy is find a thread that is a part of a citation that you want to show up in.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Gives an explicit, repeatable Reddit playbook (with a concrete Webflow example) for earning citations authentically.

quotes.topic_title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
quotes.text: But you don't actually need 10,000 comments, even five could be great and that scales perfectly well.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Counterintuitive scaling insight: a small number of high-quality contributions can outperform mass posting.

quotes.topic_title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
quotes.text: So the Reddit strategy is the obvious strategy, which is just to be an actual user of Reddit. Make an account, say who you are, say where you work, and give a useful answer.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Memorable, actionable summary of how to approach Reddit without spamming or astroturfing.

quotes.topic_title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
quotes.text: Same with Google. Google has specifically configured their search algorithm to rank Reddit and Twitter and Quora, because they want user-generated content.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Explains why UGC sources matter: major search systems intentionally boost Reddit/Twitter/Quora, making them high-leverage for citations.

quotes.topic_title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
quotes.text: Then there's RAG and RAG basically means search, retrieval-augmented generation. So I'm going to do a search and then I'm going to summarize the search. There are these two different things.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Defines a clear mental model separating core model behavior from RAG as a search-and-summarize layer practitioners can target.

quotes.topic_title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
quotes.text: And so most of what I'm describing is about the RAG piece, not the core model piece. To influence the core model is probably extremely hard and maybe you'll see the impact a year later.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: focus optimization on RAG because core-model training influence is slow and difficult.

quotes.topic_title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
quotes.text: So I'm mostly focused on the RAG side, because that's the main thing that's controllable.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concise, memorable heuristic for where practitioners should spend their effort to affect recommendations.

quotes.topic_title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
quotes.text: And I think also the LLM is probably not going to say your product if it didn't show up anywhere on the RAG. So I think that's where most of the interesting stuff is from an optimization perspective.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Counterintuitive implication: getting cited in retrieval results may matter more than trying to “train” the model to mention you.

quotes.topic_title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
quotes.text: And it's probably something, some sort of obscure thing that nobody would want to do, like make a million pages that say, "Best product for X is brand."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Concrete example illustrating how impractical it is to influence core training data compared to RAG-focused tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
quotes.text: First thing is just recognizing that this is related to search. So it's LLM plus RAG, it's summarizing a set of search results usually.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A foundational mental model for AEO: treat LLM answers as search-result retrieval plus summarization, which shapes what to optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
quotes.text: Each page is targeting hundreds, thousands, maybe tens of thousands of questions.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Reframes AEO from single-keyword optimization to topic-and-question coverage at massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
quotes.text: And if you answer a follow-up question and subtopic somebody else is not answering, you're going to be more likely to show up.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: win by covering overlooked follow-ups/subtopics competitors miss, not just the core query.

quotes.topic_title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
quotes.text: And one other interesting thing is that the majority of landing pages drive no impact. So we did an analysis where one out of 20 landing pages drive roughly 85% of all your traffic. So 19 out of 20 landing pages drive little to no traffic, which means if I want to get ROI, I need to spend a small amount of money on a large number of pages.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concrete distribution/ROI data point that challenges the “publish more pages” instinct and explains why low-quality content proliferates.

quotes.topic_title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
quotes.text: How I would solve that would be, one concept would be information gain. So did you say something that somebody else didn't say? Two is how typical are you?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for quality (and potential ranking): prioritize novelty (“information gain”) and avoid overly derivative, “typical” content.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most common things I hear from PMs and founders that I talk to is, "I know I should be speaking to customers more, but I just don't have the time or the tools." That's exactly the gap Great Question fills.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Captures a common practitioner bottleneck (time/tools) and frames the core problem-to-solution gap in customer research operations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Great Question makes it easy for anyone on your team, not just researchers, to recruit participants, run interviews, send surveys, test prototypes, and then share it all with powerful video clips.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable operational model: democratize research beyond researchers and standardize the end-to-end workflow from recruiting to sharing insights.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's everything you need to put your customers at the center of your product decisions. With a prompt as simple as, "Why did users choose us over competitors?"
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, reusable research prompt teams can apply immediately to uncover positioning and differentiation insights.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Let's give people an actual, actionable plan to start executing on this and winning essentially at AEO.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Signals a shift from theory to execution, emphasizing the need for a step-by-step plan to operationalize AEO outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
quotes.text: First, I would figure out which questions I want to rank for. How I would figure out which questions I want to rank for, I would take my search data. I would maybe take my paid search data, like, "What are my money terms? What are my competitors' money terms?"
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concrete starting point for AEO: mine your own and competitors’ paid/search data to identify high-intent “money” queries to target.

quotes.topic_title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
quotes.text: Then I would transform those into questions. And actually you can just give those keywords to ChatGPT and say, "Make these into questions," and it does a pretty good job.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable tactic for turning keyword lists into AEO-ready question targets using ChatGPT.

quotes.topic_title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
quotes.text: So what are the kinds of landing pages that are appearing? Is it a listicle? Is it a category page? Is it an article, tool page? Figure out what page type that seem to be showing up the most, and then you make your own page for that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A practical methodology: reverse-engineer the page formats that get cited and build matching page types to compete for citations.

quotes.topic_title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
quotes.text: There's not that many videos about AI-powered payment processing APIs, as interesting as that is, but it's a great money turn. So if you make a video for these really specific, high-LTV, maybe nonglamorous keywords, questions, topics, that's actually a big opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A counterintuitive channel insight: boring B2B topics can be a YouTube arbitrage opportunity because competition is low but value is high.

quotes.topic_title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
quotes.text: So SEO and AEO are both interesting in that the majority of the information and best practices are not correct.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A memorable warning that pushes practitioners toward measurement and experimentation rather than blindly following “best practices.”

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation and team setup for AEO
quotes.text: I imagine some of this is you're just giving away a lot of amazing advice for free here.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the perceived high value of the shared guidance, implying it’s unusually practical or specific for a public conversation.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation and team setup for AEO
quotes.text: First of all, I imagine there's a layer, there's only so far you can go on your own.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Suggests a limit to solo execution and hints at the need for additional support, expertise, or resources to progress further.

quotes.topic_title: Answer tracking and share of voice
quotes.text: And so you essentially need to create a share of voice across all these different things like a distribution. So how often am I showing up? What's my average rank? And that's answer tracking.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Defines the core measurement framework for AEO: treat LLM visibility as a probabilistic distribution across platforms and track share-of-voice plus average rank.

quotes.topic_title: Answer tracking and share of voice
quotes.text: So if you ask the same question, you will have different answers each time. If you ask a question, there's different answers per run. And so ChatGPT is basically calculating a distribution of all the potential answers it would give. And depending on when you ask it, it's basically like a weighted, random sample, and so you're going to get different answers.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Explains why single-run checks are misleading and why repeated querying is required to measure true visibility in LLM answers.

quotes.topic_title: Answer tracking and share of voice
quotes.text: My general suggestion is pick the cheapest one that does what you need.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Practical tool-selection advice: answer tracking is commoditized, so optimize for cost and required features rather than “premium” positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Answer tracking and share of voice
quotes.text: We did a study looking at thousands of questions and saw the citation overlap with Google Search results was around 35% for ChatGPT and Google, so not that much.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point showing ChatGPT citations diverge significantly from Google, implying AEO needs surface-specific measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Answer tracking and share of voice
quotes.text: Perplexity was around 70%, but essentially they're all similar algorithms, but with very different citations and results.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: even with similar underlying approaches, different LLM/search surfaces produce materially different sources and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Which LLM platforms matter and why
quotes.text: Well, the way that I would answer that is I believe AOL was one of the largest search engines early on and Google was not. And so we could ask in 1999 or whatever, "Should we just focus on AOL search and Yahoo search? Do we really need to worry about Google?" And the answer is we don't actually know.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Uses a historical analogy to caution against over-optimizing for today’s apparent leader because platform winners can change fast.

quotes.topic_title: Which LLM platforms matter and why
quotes.text: It's very early, we don't know who's going to win.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A simple uncertainty principle that argues for hedging rather than committing all effort to one LLM ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Which LLM platforms matter and why
quotes.text: Just like search, I think that there will probably be multiple winners and probably you'll need to optimize for several.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat LLM optimization as multi-platform SEO, not a single-engine strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Which LLM platforms matter and why
quotes.text: I don't think that you'll need to optimize for 10, but there'll probably be around three or so that will win that you want to optimize for.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Provides a practical planning heuristic for how many LLM platforms to prioritize long-term.

quotes.topic_title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
quotes.text: So for most B2B questions, the answers are not clickable. There's nothing to click on. And so if you actually want to measure the impact, you cannot just look at last-touch referral traffic. You have to see whether or not you showed up in the answer with tracking. And then you also need to ask the user, "How did you hear about us post-conversion to actually know the impact?"
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A practical measurement framework for B2B AEO where traditional attribution (last-touch traffic) fails because answers often aren’t linkable.

quotes.topic_title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
quotes.text: So it's harder to track for B2B. Also for B2B, you're probably deciding which payroll management software to use after 50 touchpoints. With a brand, it's not going to be you just search for something, you suddenly spent $100,000 on payroll management software.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A concrete example and data point (“50 touchpoints”) that explains why B2B AEO impact is diffuse and attribution needs to be multi-touch.

quotes.topic_title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
quotes.text: So if you ask, "What's the best TV for apartments?" There are actual shoppable cards. Those shoppable cards are showing multiple sellers. Those sellers have rich snippets. Schema is important, the number of reviews are important, so it's actually quite different. You can look at last-touch referral traffic to get a good sense about the number of conversions that you're getting.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable commerce AEO guidance: optimize schema and reviews because AI results can be directly shoppable and measurable via referral traffic.

quotes.topic_title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
quotes.text: So I mentioned earlier, early stage my recommendation is don't do SEO at all. For Answer Engine Optimization, definitely do AEO, and only do citation optimization and long tail. Don't do any of the mid-SEO stuff, just get cited and answer really specific questions.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A counterintuitive early-stage playbook: skip traditional SEO and focus narrowly on citations plus long-tail, high-intent questions.

quotes.topic_title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
quotes.text: Meaning the citations that show up for B2B versus marketplaces are different kinds of citations. So for B2B, it might be like TechRadar shows up a ton when I ask questions. I've never read TechRadar, but for some reason it shows up all the time. I'm sure it's great. But TechRadar is showing up a ton for B2B for whatever reason.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A specific example showing that citation targets differ by category, implying you must map and optimize for the sources LLMs actually cite in your niche.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
quotes.text: And then they'll click on your domain, and you will think that it was a branded Google Search when it wasn't.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Highlights an attribution pitfall where LLM-driven discovery gets misclassified as branded search, skewing channel reporting and ROI decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
quotes.text: Or they'll open up a new tab and they will type in your domain, and they'll go directly to your domain and you'll falsely think that it was direct traffic.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Warns that LLM influence can masquerade as “direct” visits, meaning LLM impact may be undercounted unless you adjust measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
quotes.text: Yes. And I would give the same answer that Brian Balfour gave on your previous episode on this, which is that it's not your choice whether to play the game. You are playing the game whether you want to or not, so you might as well try to show up. If you just say, "Don't look at any of my data," then you cannot show up and your competitors will.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: opting out of LLM visibility is effectively choosing to cede distribution to competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
quotes.text: Now, what you can do is you can say, "I don't want you to train on my data, so you can index my site, but please don't train on my data." And they have different user agents for that and different bots, so you can just say, "And we're building a Webflow app to block training but not indexation."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Actionable tradeoff: allow indexing for discoverability while blocking training via bot/user-agent controls to protect content.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
quotes.text: Or you can just put it in your robots.txt, "This training bot not allowed. Index bot, you are allowed." So if you're concerned about that, I would suggest that, and I think probably a lot of people will do that. But saying, "You can't index my site at all," that doesn't make sense to me.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Smith
quotes.context: Provides a concrete implementation approach (robots.txt split between training vs indexing) and argues against blanket no-index policies.
